content.description: A great route.  The crux is just after the first bolt, but stays hard to the top.  A great steep route, if it were longer it would get 4 stars
content.location: This is the route at the back of the cave and the meets with cracked lip at the 4th bolt.

content.description: 3 low grade ~5.6 routes exist on a  west facing rock away from the main wall. Across the gravel road and down the slope. This is my recommended location for taking beginners out within the Ogden area. The top is accessible for top roping, routes are easy enough for first time lead climbers/belayers, and the anchors are great for learning top belay, abseiling, cleaning, etc.
content.location: West of the main wall across the gravel road and down the slope. It can also be approached from below.

content.description: This route follows the obvious flake system out of the cave, the hardest move on the route is probably the one getting off the ground, but the redpoint crux is right at the third bolt making a leftward traverse before gaining the easy ground past the last bolt to the chains. Fun and interesting movement throughout the overhanging lower portion of the climb. Lots of drop knees and even a knee bar or two will help you surmount this route.
content.location: This route starts just a tiny bit to the left of the poison ivy in the cave.  The start is shared with THC which begins with the first bolt line right of Crystal Method. It starts on the obvious chalked undercling with poor feet.  Climb the first two bolts of THC, then continue straight up to the third bolt of Crystal Method, finishing up with a bit of a runout to a lone bolt in the easy but kind of awkward corner system above.

content.description: Start on two hand awkward side pull just left of Hankerin. High feet put you inverted on the first move so a stick clip is a good idea. Route follows a left leaning feature. Midway route splits go right. For a more moderate finish go left I don't know the name on the line going left. Due to the hard star going left is still 5.12c.

This is an easy 3 bolt route on the east face of the large rock that sits about 50 feet south east of the main 9th street area.  The crux of the route is between the second and third bolts.  The route is mostly a jug haul, but it is slightly overhanging.
content.location: East face of the large rock about 50 feet south of the east side of the main ninth street area.

content.description: I don't know what the true name of this route is or who the first ascent is, but I heard it called Reverse Traverse today and the name fits.  This is a link-up of Vile of Crack to Cleft Lip and gives you the cruxes of both routes plus some additional harder climbing as you make the reverse of the crux traverse moves on cracked lip.  This certainly bumps the grade up a bit from Vile of Crack and probably puts it in at around 5.11d or easy 5.12a.
content.protection: clip the first two bolts of Vile of Crack, then the last three bolts of Cleft Lip,  Ends at the two chain anchor of both routes.
content.location: Link-up of Vile of Crack and Cleft Lip.

content.description: Fun climb and a good first time lead. After the 2nd bolt you can go straight up for a 5.9 or veer to the right for a 5.8 experience. Late afternoon during the summer finds the climb in shade - still warm, but not too hot (although the rock retains a lot of heat, so don't forget your chalk!)
content.location: The third farthest left route (left of Cub Scout Corner). Easy to find as it is the third bolted route on 9th street on the left as you look at the wall.

content.description: This is a new route that is the furthest route left on the wall.  The crux was right at the second bolt where there weren't a ton of holds and it was a bit more technical.  The rock is still cleaning up and had a lot of sections with loose stuff still on it, though all of the big holds appeared to be solid.
content.location: Far left side of the crag.

content.description:
Noticed this route when we setup our top rope for Nerve Damage and this route was much more in line with the anchor. We were able to climb Nerve Damage and then this route back to back, making it a nice bang for our buck setup wise.

Since we didn't have any trad gear we hiked up around the back of the rock face to get to the anchor. Up top there is a large rock with a bolt that we used to lower to the route anchor so that we could set it up safely.

A different start to Nerve Damage as it merges half way up. Fairly obvious start at the bottom with a nice jug and left hand pocket for a few fingers. Throw a left foot out and catch it on the out cropping rock. From here I had to stiff arm with my right and bring up my right foot. At this point I had to shimmy up with my feet a bit as holds are fairly sparse. There are two pretty good crimpers on the right, and after a bit of shimmying I could grab with my right and then match hands on it. Feet placement at this point are pretty tricky and I think I was more or less smearing. After that you can either try and make a big move to the nice jug, try continuing to smear up, or use the fairly good hold to the top left that's apart of Community Service. That hold specifically probably keeps the route in the 10a/b range. If you do it without I'd say 10b range due to the cruxy-ness of it. From there the jug leads into the last half of Nerve Damage.
content.location: Between Nerve Damage and Community Service.

content.description: Located to the left of genius and to the right of community service. The first 3-5 moves are the hardest. Very fun underclings and balance.
content.protection: 2 rings for top rope. Good crack to place trad gear.

content.description: Fun, powerful moves to pull the roof.
content.protection: There is an old piton under the roof, and one bolt over the roof. The start can be protected with a few TCU's. Shares an anchor with Midnight Cowboy.
content.location: This is the only climb with 1 bolt. It is just west of the "big" roof.

content.description: Start on vile of crack traverse right at second bolt. Keep going right until you join THC. If you go up after traversing one bolt it is about 12b. I don't know the name of that one.

This is a linkup that shares the start with "Vile of Crack", and "Like Pull'n Teeth".  After the second bolt of Vile of Crack, start heading right as for Like Pull'n Teeth and clip the first bolt of that route.  This is where the crux is encountered as you make a couple of big moves on small holds.  After pulling through the crux, head straight up into the corner system and finish on the unknown 5.12c.
content.location: Shares start with Vile of Crack and Like Pull'n Teeth, shares the finish up the corner with THCrystal Corner.

content.description: Fun short route would get a lot more stars if it were just longer. Works up easy for 10 feet to first bolt.  Heads left using an awesome flake with some good crimpers after it. once you turn the roof you are at the chains. The crux is at the third bolt.
content.location:
This route is  the second bolted line right of

Cub Scout Corner

.

content.description: This is a new route found just to the left of Shino and is now the second route from the left side of the crag.  The route is great for beginners and really doesn't have any hard moves, but the crux is probably right at the 3rd bolt where you have to get a high foot on a big ledge to make a slightly reachy move.  This route felt much cleaner than the other new route to the left of it.
content.location: Second route from the left side of the crag just to the left of Shino.

content.description: A sharp rock alcove on top of the hill. It had a slight overhang with a window inside the alcove. Hornets inhabit some of the pockets look before you hold.
content.location: On the hill above Potter's wall. Window is visible from the top of the wall, accessed from the north via Bonneville Shoreline.

content.description: Steep roof at the bottom with big holds. Stick clip the first bolt. Once over the lip, the climbing is strenuous and sparse. There are some good holds, but you need to put the sequence together carefully.
content.protection: four bolts to sport anchors. the space between the last bolt and the anchor is a little runout.
content.location: left hand side of the overhanging area on the 9th street wall.

content.description: This route shares the start and the crux with Hankerin'.  Start up the blank nearly featurless rock using the few key holds available to reach the third bolt.  At this point continue straight up clipping another bolt before joining the upper section of Crank Addiction Direct Finish.  Very interesting moves through the lower crux.
content.protection: Bolts, 7 I think to a 2 bolt anchor with chains.
content.location: Starts just right of the poison ivy.  This first bolt is at eye level so that is a good indicator that it's the right route.  I'd just skip it and stick clip the second.

content.description: Small holds down low. At first bolt reach big out left and let and let the technical climbing began. Original finish on Just like pull'n teeth but can be finished on Crank Addiction direct.
content.location: Between THC and Crank Addiction

content.description: Shares first 2 bolts of Crank Addiction then goes up left line of bolts. First bolts are spaced out. A fall on going to bolt 2 could deck.

This is an easier route that shares the last bolt and chains with Edge of Madness to the right.  Begin with technical insecure climbing up to the bulge, then continue over the bulge with some more insecure moves until you get the big jugs just before joining Edge of Madness at it's last bolt.  From here just continue up the jugs to the anchors.
content.location: This is the second to last route on the right side of the crag between Community Service and Edge of Madness.

content.description: This is the route on the farthest right hand side of the 9th street wall. The crux is at the bottom. Thin holds and tricky moves lead to steep rock with nice jugs at the top.
content.location: last climb on the east (right hand) side of the wall. gets afternoon sun.

content.description:
This is the hard looking line of bolts directly to the right of Vile of Crack that goes straight up through the hardest part of the roof.

Probably easiest to boulder it out with large pads and solo to the anchor/top.
Bouldery start leads to easy slab climbing above. The first few moves are tricky making it a good idea to use a stick clip for the first and maybe second bolts.
content.location: last route on the right most side of the 'cave' area. You can easily TR the route, by walking around to the top of the crag.

content.description: Easiest route on 9th Street Crag.  Very easy to top rope with two chains.
content.location: As you are heading east up the incline, this is the second set of chains.  It is around a corner slightly.

content.description: Big holds mixed with some fun traversing small stuff.  This is a great route that takes a short crag and makes a long route out of it.  The Crux is making the final traversing part over to where vile of crack continues up.
content.location: This route starts at the very left of the opening of the cave.  It is the same start as Jerusalem but most don't clip the same first bolt.  Once you reach the roof it clips the first bolt to the right and continues moving right until you get to vile of crack.  Once you reach Vile go up and send

content.description: This is a fun route up a slabby section of rock that doesn't climb much like a slab route.  Start of with some fun technical stemming to get to the first bolt, then some trickery will get you up to the clipping jug for the second bolt.  From there some easy climbing leads you past the third bolt, then at the fourth head to the right around the corner and straight up to the anchors.  This route faces east, so it is in the shade most of the time which is nice for warmer days.
content.location: This route is the third route from the right side of the crag.

content.description: Same start as Cracked Lip - go straight up after you clear the roof.  The crux is on the face just above the roof as most of the hold are thin and crimpy.  Fun route!
content.location: 5th bolted route from the left of the crag.  Starts just under the roof.  Shares chains with Cracked Lip.

content.description:
Because this route is not bolted, and there are no anchors at the top, it does not get climbed that often.

To set up the TR, build an anchor with trad gear at the top. There are two good boulders you can sling as well. Drop the anchors that attach to the rope through the obvious "V" in the rock.

The bottom of the route has several different paths. One climbs out over a bulge and then moves right into a little dihedral. The next follows the dihedral (to the right of the bulge) from the ground up.

Then it is a little slabby up to the headwall which overhangs.  The overhanging part is the crux. There are a couple of cool moves up to some big holds. There is a nice gaston in the middle. Moving left makes it a bit easier.
content.protection: No pro. build an anchor on top and set up the top rope.
content.location:
This route is just to the right of

Cubscout Corner

on the far left hand side of the wall. It is also just to the left of

Midnight Cowboy

and

Mr. Interruptus

. The overhang at the top of the wall with the V shaped notch at the very top is the distinguishing mark.

content.description: Crimpy climbing split with a undercling rest. Crux move is right after clipping the first bolt then fight the pump to the top as the top half of the route is slightly overhanging.
content.location: Right between Jerusalem and Mr. Interruptus. You can start at the begining of either route and head to the bolt at the start of Bolt Sandwich. Can be easily TR'd.

content.description:
This route covers the entire wall, from "The Reach Around" to "Genius/Edge of Madness", with fun movement throughout.

The main crux is moving up "Jerusalem", over to "Cleft Lip", then down and through the crux of "Cracked Lip". After that, belay at the chains for "Like Pull'n a Tooth/Teeth".

The second pitch is much easier, if more run out. It's a bit of a choose your own adventure anywhere from 5.9 to 5.11 depending on how high or low you go. Bring a few cams to prevent a really bad fall (BD #3 and #0.5 work well). Belay at chains for "Edge of Madness".
content.protection:
Mostly uses the bolts encountered on the traverse but many of them need to be extended to reduce rope drag, and prevent decking.

A 24' "mega-draw" was used to protect the moves between "Bring Your Lunch" and "Midnight Cowboy".

Bring a few cams for the second pitch to make things a little safer.

There are a handful of places that if you blow the clip you might deck. It's safer to take the fall without the extra slack out if you're pumped.
content.location:
Begin on the starting holds for "The Reach Around" and angle up toward the first bolt on "Shino".

Where this is the most used crag in Ogden, please be courteous - this route takes up the whole wall.

content.description: This route is located between Cub Scout Corner and Midnight Cowboy. The crux is the finishing moves. If you send the overhang directly, then you will want to skip the last bolt. For lead climbers with less experience rather than send the overhang directly go hard right and use the system of hand jugs to approach the chains, make sure that if you do it this way you protect yourself with the bolt to the right.
